Evelyn is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell for her general store business.

Evelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 26 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Tamari

texts.en:
Tamari is a 21-year-old young woman from Kutaisi city, west Georgia. She lives with her sister and her husband, who is employed at a private financial organization. Tamari earns a living with the help of her parents' transfers, who live abroad and try to make financial stability for their daughters. 

In spite of her high education, Tamari was unable to start any stable job. So she decided to start her own business and generate her own income. She requested a loan from local financial institutions several times, but without any success, as they require stable income or business experience. The joint initiative between Kiva and Credo enabled her to get a loan of 1,900 USD for buying a commercial space at a good location and, after renovation, rent it at a good price. 

This mentioned activity will be great support for this young woman, as she will be able to make savings and for the future expand her business in other fields. 

Tamari relies on the goodwill of lenders and will be really grateful for the help.

loans.use: To buy a commercial space and rent it

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en: Loreta always has enthusiasm managing her farming activities, from which she earns an income that primarily supports her family.  Now she started her corn production. At the age of 52 and married, she busies herself to sufficiently provide for the family. She grabbed the opportunity to become a full-fledged member of PMPC. She credits the cooperative for her capital in supporting her farming activities. Recently she applied for a loan to buy bags of fertilizer and compost for a more productive corn harvest. In the future, Loreta wishes to see all her children finish their studies and get stable jobs in the future.

loans.use: to buy bags of fertilizer and compost for a more productive corn harvest

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina, a hardworking widow with four adult-age children, is from Tudela, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is 58 years old, and she ventures in a snack vending business in order to survive. Cristina has applied her membership with PMPC, and she appreciates the programs and services of the Coop. 

She is in need of additional capital to purchase raw ingredients like, flour, sugar, margarine, etc. to increase her production of "shakoy" (bread roll) to provide for more customers. She asked for financial assistance from Paglaum MPC in the amount of PHP 10,500 and is thankful for the financing for her capital needs. She wants to expand her business and to build a good business management for her loyal customers. With her extra income, she deeply wishes to provide her family a descent and comfortable life.

loans.use: to purchase additional raw ingredients like, flour, sugar, margarine, etc. to increase her production of "shakoy" (bread roll) to provide for more customers.

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
In 2011, Belen learned about Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative and the financial assistance it offers. Belen tried her luck doing farming activities, focusing on her corn production business. She feels she owes her fortune to the Cooperative for having trusted her with the money she used as capital. 

Belen borrowed another amount to pay for additional fertilizer and compost to increase crop yield on her corn farm. This will help her to generate more income to provide for the family. Belen seeks better business ideas and strategies in farming, and would love to be in the position to help others.

loans.use: to pay for additional fertilizer and compost to increase her crop yield.

location.town: Tudela-Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Mind

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
Ricardo is married and has children. He is known in the Ozamiz City area being a hard working and responsible father. Ricardo is dedicated to his work as a driver. 

Ricardo requested a loan from PMPC for 50,000 PHP, which he will use to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks to improve living conditions for the family. He hopes to live comfortably with a decent house.

loans.use: to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks to improve living conditions for the family

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is 60 years old and married with five children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a loan of 11,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy items to sell such as shampoo and groceries.

Merlita has taken out and repaid 30 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 11 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Merlita aspires to build and expand her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to buy items to sell such as shampoo and groceries

loans.name: Jennylyn

texts.en:
Jennylyn is gaining a profit through her sari-sari (small grocery) store business. At the age of 29 and married, she never gets tired of tending her store. She is driven by her passion in selling, and she earns a meager income from it that sufficiently supports her family. Jennylyn is a full-fledged member of PMPC and has taken several loans already. She maintains her membership in good standing without record of default. 

Now she has applied for a loan to purchase additional goods for her store like canned goods, shampoo, soap, soft drinks and noodles to increase stock. Jennylyn continues to pursue her goals and look for better business opportunities, proof that she has the determination and strong will to make ends meet for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items like canned goods, shampoo, soap, soft drinks and noodles to increase stock.

loans.name: Isidora

texts.en: Isidora is a 42-year-old widow with two children. She and her children live in Ozamiz City, Philippines. Isidora is diligent and persevering when it comes to the welfare of her family; she has always been known to provide the best for her family. She is earning a living through snack vending. To generate more income, Isidora decided to give seaweed cultivation a try after she learned that she could avail herself of financial assistance from PMPC. Consequently, she requested a loan to buy a boat and other materials needed for this project. Isidora has the help and support of her children and smiles at the thought of having a comfortable life and providing them with a good education.

loans.use: to buy a boat and other materials needed to cultivate seaweed.

loans.name: Carmen Margot

texts.es:
La historia de carmen es algo difícil de contar, una lágrima llega al rostro de una persona  al saber lo que paso y lo más impactante es como reacciono esta mujer que tiene un corazón gigante y que sigue luchando por mejorar su calidad de vida.  

Carmen es una mujer desplazada por la violencia es madre de 7 hijos de 10, 14, 18, 20, 24, 28, 13 años de edad, su hijo de 14 años (ver foto) sufre de una enfermedad terminal de intestino y ha luchado 5 años con esta enfermedad lo que le ha impedido a Carmen trabajar y luchar por una mejor calidad de vida, pero al historia no termina su hija mayor se fue al ecuador dejándole su hijo de 10 años y desde ese entonces se desapareció y el hijo creció diciéndole mamá a Carmen, aparte el hijo de 13 años de edad lo adopto de un compañero ya que iba a quedar en la calle y ella lo acogió en su amoroso seno. 
Pero está mujer a pesar de sus problemas, de su estado económico no se rinde y quiere solicitar un crédito para iniciar su negocio de venta de comidas rápidas el cual ubicara en su casa, buscando mejorar su calidad de vida puesto que no le gusta ir de casa en casa pidiendo o mendigando una moneda para vivir quiere trabajar y luchar por salir adelante con su familia.
El crédito solicitado será para la compra de un carro de comidas (ver foto), insumos, herramienta, y materia prima para elaborar sus preparaciones, gaseosas, panes, carne, ensaladas, etc. Etc. 
Carmen pide que le ayuden apoyando su proyecto, ella quiere que sus hijos vivan bien, que no les falte nada y puedan estudiar pues la pobreza no es una excusa para rendirse.
texts.en:
Carmen’s story is somewhat difficult to tell.  A tear comes to the eye knowing what happened.  The thing that impacts you the most is how this woman, who has a giant heart, reacted and continues struggling to improve her quality of life.

Carmen is a displaced woman because of violence.  She has 7 children, ages 10, 14, 18, 20, 24, 28, and 13.  Her 14 year old son (see photo) suffers from a terminal intestinal disease.  He has struggled for five years with this disease, which has kept Carmen from working and struggling for a better quality of life.

However, the story does not end here.  Her oldest daughter went to Ecuador and left her ten year old son.  Ever since her daughter went away, her son grew up calling Carmen mother.  She adopted her 13 year old son from a companion because he was going to be left on the street.  She welcomed him into her loving heart.

This woman, in spite of her problems and her financial situation, does not give up.  She wants to request a loan to start her business of selling fast foot at her house.  She is looking to improve her quality of life.  She does not like going from house to house asking or begging for money in order to live.  She wants to work and struggle to get ahead with her family.

The requested loan will be to buy a food cart (see photo), supplies, tools, and raw material to make soft drinks, bread, meat, and salads, etc.  Carmen asks that you help her by supporting her project.  She wants her children to live well and not be in need.  She wants them to go to school because poverty is not an excuse to give up.

loans.use: to start a business of selling fast food.  This is a striking story of a woman with a big heart.

loans.name: Sumbuloy

texts.en:
This is Sumbuloy. She is an enterprising and active woman from Yavan district. Sumbuloy is 44 years old, married and has three children. Her daughter is already married, and Sumbuloy lives with her two sons and husband. 

Sumbuloy is engaged in a family trading business. Five years ago, she and her husband started business in the sphere of clothing sales. They sell children's and women's clothes in their retail outlet in the market. They love their activity; it is the only source of family income. 

Sumbuloy is applying for a loan. She intends to purchase seasonal children's clothing for increasing sales. 

Sumbuloy has big plans for the future. At the expense of the profit from the business, she wants to hold the ceremony of circumcision of her younger son, and make renovations in the house.

This loan will assist her to realize her goals.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal children's clothing

loans.name: Aya

texts.en:
Aya is a 20-year-old single young lady from Jabalia. She lives with her family in a small humble house. Her brother works as an employee in the public sector with a low income, which is the only source of income for the family. Aya is a student in a local university where she studies science; she is in her second year. She would like to earn a BA degree and find a job as a teacher to support her family. 

Aya has applied for a loan from FATEN to help her to buy a new laptop for her studies. By taking this loan, Aya will be able to do her homework and write her reports more easily. 

Aya appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for her study.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 28 years old, married, and together with his spouse they have been blessed with two children. He sells phones and phones accessories and has been in this business for three years. 

He will be using this loan to buy more stock of phones, phone chargers, phone batteries, and covers to sell. This will enable him to serve more customers and thereby get more income in his business. He will use the anticipated profits to support his family by providing for the basic needs. 

This is his fifth loan term with VisionFund Kenya, and he paid his previous loans successfully. His future hopes are to expand his business and live a better life.

loans.use: To buy more stock of phones and phone accessories.

loans.name: Melody

texts.en:
Her name is Melody, 32, a resident of Coron, Palawan, Philippines. Married to Leonilo, a fish vendor, and has three children, one is in high school, one in the elementary level, and the other one not of school age yet. She manages her household while operating the business. She works hard to augment their income to support and meet their daily personal and household needs, and to send her children to school. 

Melody has operated a general store for five years already. In the Philippines, a general store is basically a small convenience store which sells fresh, dry, and packaged commodities directly to consumers. Almost all products are essential household items and food. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this, she also sells fish.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum net income of Php 1,000 a day. 

To help her continue operations of her general store business, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan which she will use to buy grocery items such as fresh meat, sacks of rice, charcoal, soda, and other grocery stuff. She is positive that it will boost her income as she expands her business. Her earnings is their source to meet their daily expenses, and to send her children to school. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her.

Melody hopes to maintain and grow her business so they could have a better life. She strives to hard to give her children the best education possible and prays for a quiet and happy life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, beverages, and toiletries to sell.

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora makes a living through her retailing business. She has signed up for her membership with PMPC to gain access of capitalization. She wants to increase her inventory. 

Now, she availed a loan to purchase bananas, oil, and sugar.  Aurora hopes to sustain her snack vending business and dreams to send all her children to school.

loans.use: To purchase bananas, oil, and sugar

location.town: Oroquieta-Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occ

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 46 years old and lives in Ozamiz City, Philippines. She is married with six children. Marilyn has a furniture shop and offers services such as wood carving and producing molding. She has had this business for 20 years.

Marilyn requested a loan to purchase more types of wood to produce a greater variety of furniture. Marilyn has been a member of PMPC for 8 years now. In the future, she hopes to own a furniture showroom to attract more customers.

loans.use: to purchase more types of wood to produce a greater variety of furniture

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling rice in the Philippines.  She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy sacks of rice to sell for her rice business. Esther has been in this business for 10 years. She also earns more income from farming vegetables.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses. Esther has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice to sell for her business.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Joy works hard to support her family. She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pre-paid mobile load. Joy is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock of household goods to sell like canned goods, eggs, noodles, etc. for her general store business.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses. Joy has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business, to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of household goods to sell like canned goods, eggs, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a farming of rice business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 19,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to purchase additional rice seeds and fertilizers for her rice farming business.

Yolanda has been in this business for 11 years. Yolanda earns additional income from motorcycle transport.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Yolanda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional rice seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Leonesa

texts.en:
Leonesa is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buying and selling of ginger business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 14,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy additional ginger to sell in her ginger business.

Leonesa has been in this business for 15 years. Leonesa earns more income from a general store and buying and selling charcoal.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Leonesa has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional ginger to sell for her business

loans.name: Jafali

texts.en:
Jafari is 49 years old, married, and has four children. He lives in Kamwenge, Uganda. He used his previous loan to buy petrol to sell. Jafari also practices farming alongside petrol selling. 

Jafari is requesting for a loan, which he will use to buy manure for his banana farm. He still has hopes of expanding his business into a big petrol station.

loans.use: to purchase manure for his banana farm.

loans.name: Denis

texts.en:
The humid and rocky Cheplanget area within the Kericho County can be considered a hardship area. Even with savannah plains and little human activity, there exists a farm that stands tall, a farm with more than three high-pedigreed Friesian cows, producing over 30 litres of milk. It’s quite an outstanding feat, considering the harsh terrain and other handicaps, like the lack of electricity from the national grid and dependence on traditional methods of harvesting water.

Meet Denis, the man credited with the success story of this farm. He is a loving husband and has been farming for the past four years. Denis passionately loves dairy farming, and this can be attested to by the fact that he knows his cows, each individually, because he works with them twice a day, 365 days a year. He and his wife have even named one of them “Toleltol” meaning the brown one. Because he loves the cows, he runs his operation by four simple rules that have kept him and his herd happy. The rules are: breed them well, feed them well, clean them well and milk them well. His primary source of income has been milk, eggs, crops and some personal business that he engages in to make ends meet. The income he makes from selling milk, eggs and crops is insufficient to meet his family's expenses, but he is hopeful that he will improve. 

He is seeking a loan from Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva lenders to buy a quality dairy cow. Juhudi Kilimo serves poor smallholder farmers in Kenya. This is a severely marginalized group with little access to financial services. By extending credit to the farmers, Juhudi helps them acquire assets like dairy cows, poultry, irrigation equipment, and greenhouses. Through this loan from Kiva lenders Denis will buy not just an ordinary cow but a quality breed of cow that will be producing between 10-20 litres of milk a day. The additional milk will result in additional income and hence improved living conditions. The income generated from selling the milk will be used to fully repay the loan, and will help with the education of his child. He will benefit from the cow manure which will be used to increase the fertility level of his farm, hence increasing productivity. Through the loan he will also be able to build a bio-gas digester that will be helpful in saving energy. This loan will completely change his life and improve his living conditions. Denis waits for your kindness.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Dickson

texts.en:
As a father to 2 children, the great desire to see them all grow up to be professionals is what fills Dickson with enthusiasm and inspiration. Dickson is 25 years old and works tirelessly to raise animals. Through these humble tasks, he aspires to offer all of his children a university education. Dickson learned to do farm work at a young age, thanks to his parents. He has a tiny plot of land to live off – just under half an acre – and has always struggled to support his family. 

Dickson has developed the farm in the sloping undulating terrain by successfully adopting suitable soil and water conservation methods such as stone pitched bench terracing and digging rain water storage pits. For over five years his income source has been from selling milk, poultry, and vegetables. He supplements the meager income by doing other personal  business. Dickson passionately loves dairy farming. Milking and feeding his own cow is the most enjoyable part about farming. He is very appreciative that dairy farming has been able to sustain farmers in his village. Milk, poultry and vegetables are very perishable, and these products require timely delivery to the market, but one problem that he faces is delivering to the market on time. 

Kitale area has a poor road network and poor feeder roads that really hamper timely delivery of products to the market; that is why Dickson is kindly seeking a loan to buy a motorbike. Farmers like Dickson will use the motorbike to transport passengers and farm goods to and from the market. They are suited for areas with poor road networks which are inaccessible by cars. They are also very cheap to acquire and maintain. 

Invest in Dickson’s future and you won't regret it. He is full of promise. So far, he has managed to send his children to standard private schools with his blood, sweat, and tears. Imagine what he will do with your lending?

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Choi Aan Lom Group

texts.en:
Phakhochong is an energetic and active woman who gives her best effort for the well-being of her family. “I love my family and they are my source of inspiration everyday. I will do all things that contribute to the well-being of my family,” said Phakhochong, 40 years old. 

She is pictured with the other members of the group and featured with her hand raised. Her husband sold firewood and charcoal for sustenance of the family, which was not reliable due to the inaccessibility of vehicles in the area and lead to failure in his business. 

She joined the Choi Aan group in the year 2010 with the hope of achieving financial stability and started earning money by running a tea stall in her native village, which consists of around 65 households. She makes tea and roti (pancake) to sell to customers and also sells other grocery items in the tea stall.

The tea stall has been the main source of income for the family. She supports four school-going children from the income she earns from the tea stall. The income was sufficient for their family until they had to pay the fees of a minor operation for the eldest one. Since then, they were short of finances every now and then, and she could hardly manage to buy materials needed for her tea stall. She cannot pay for the children’s school fees regularly after that. 

She aspires to revive her tea stall and her family's financial condition by buying more inventory for the tea stall so that she can sell more items to attract customers. With the Kiva loan, she will buy more stock of inventory to sell. She will provide school fees and the articles required for the household. 

She sends good wishes to the lenders for their kind act. The rest of the group members are hardworking. They are engaged in similar business, including a grocery store, poultry, a vegetable business, livestock, weaving and a piggery, to become self-reliant.

loans.use: to buy inventory for her tea stall to sell.

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is a single woman and owns a house that has piped water, but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food.
 
Rachael has operated a tailoring business for the past four years. She makes women's suits and men's suits. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future. 

With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. 

She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread

loans.name: Visaminda

texts.en:
In 2012, Visaminda applied for membership in PMPC after she learned about the benefits the Co-op offers to its members. She became a member in good standing and has received several loans that were all repaid in a timely manner.

Visaminda is married and has a school-age daughter; her husband is a farmer, and they live in Molave, Zamboanga del Sur. Visaminda is an ordinary minimum-wage earner employed by a private company. She supports the daily needs of their family. She is a persevering mother who wants nothing more than to see her only daughter get her diploma and a stable job.

Visaminda is in need of financial assistance. She requested a loan of 50,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to pay for her daughter's school expenses this school year. Someday, she hopes to build a concrete house for the family.

loans.use: to pay for her daughter's school expenses for this school year

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: At the age of 64, Norma is still earning an income through her sari-sari or variety store business. She lives with her family in Leyte, Philippines. Norma has been in the business for more than a year now. Her husband is a carpenter. Norma is asking for a loan to buy more stocks to sell like rice, canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, cooking oil and condiments, biscuits and snack foods.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell like rice, canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, cooking oil and condiments, biscuits and snack foods

loans.name: Kuña Aty Group

texts.es:
El grupo Kuña Aty está en el ciclo número 9 del programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, donde todas trabajan y se ayudan por salir adelante. Se ha hecho la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza en donde tres señoras se encontraban dentro de la línea de la pobreza, pero ya se ha trabajado con ella para que vayan progresando poco a poco.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Yrene  ella es la presidenta general del Comité, quien se dedica al comercio, es decir a la venta de productos varios desde hace tiempo. Gracias a esta actividad ella puede mantener su casa e ir aumentando sus ingresos para ayudar a su familia. Su esposo también trabaja y  de esa forma se ayudan en familia para poder trabajar.
La Sra. Yrene solicita este préstamo para la compra de jabones, aceite, verduras, hortalizas, shampoo y demás,  ya que tiene mucha clientela a quienes quiere seguir satisfaciendo. Ella es una mujer muy trabajadora y luchadora.
texts.en:
The Kuña Aty group is in its ninth cycle with the Committee of Enterprising Women program, where they all work and help each other get ahead in life.  They have completed the Poverty Elimination Survey, where three of the Señoras were found to be below the poverty line, but they are already working so that they can progress little by little.

One of the members is Señora Yrene.  She is the general president of the Committee, and for some time she has made a living through the sale of various products.  Thanks to this job, she can maintain her house and increase her income in order to support her family.  Her husband also works, and in this way they help the family get ahead.

Señora Yrene asks for the loan in order to buy soap, oil, vegetables, shampoo, and other items, since she has many customers whom she wants to continue to satisfy.  She is a very hardworking and tough woman.

loans.use: to buy soap, oil, vegetables, shampoo, and other items.

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en: Oliver is married with two children and lives in Tudela, Misamis Occidental. He makes a living operating a sari-sari (small grocery) store business. He is a determined father who never loses hope in pursuing his goals despite the challenges he faces. He never gets tired tending his store since he is driven by his desire to be able to support his family. Oliver is a full fledged member of PMPC and has taken several loans already. He maintains his membership in good standing without any record of defaults. Now, he has applied for a loan to purchase additional stocks for his sari-sari (small grocery) store in order to serve more customers. This will allow him to increase his sales and grow his busi for the benefit of his family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks for his sari-sari (small grocery) store in order  to attract more customers

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Ruth works hard to support her family. She has a dressmaking business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. Ruth is borrowing 11,000 PHP through NWTF to buy clothing and tailoring materials for her dressmaking business.

Ruth has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy clothing and tailoring materials for her business

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie is 42 years old and married with four children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, sardines, candies, etc. to sell.

Margie has previously borrowed and re-paid three loans from NWTF. She has been running the general store for eight years and also earns an income from fish vending, rice retailing, and raising pigs.

Margie aspires to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo, sardines, candies, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish-vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell for her fish-vending business.

Letecia successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

NWTF is listing Letecia's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Ismail

texts.en:
Ismail is a male aged twenty-four, married with three children, and living in Bundibugyo-Uganda. His business is motorcycle transport and he likes his job because he gets money that helps him provide the basic necessities of life for his family. He also has a cocoa garden that supplements his income from the business. He is affected by the poor roads in Bundibugyo, particularly because of the hills.

He is requesting for a loan to buy a motor cycle for his transportation business.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for his transportation business.

loans.name: Njira

texts.en:
Njira is a married woman with three kids, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that does not have either electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Njira operates a grocery stall selling vegetables. She sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. A challenge for her is the high cost of transportation to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a general store in the future.

With the loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), Njira wants to purchase green vegetables, crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale

loans.name: Genoveva

texts.en:
As a married mother of five children, Genoveva works hard to support her family.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising chickens. Genoveva is borrowing PHP 50000 through NWTF in order to buy more fish to resell at her fish vending business.

Genoveva has been sustaining her business activities through her past 20 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more fish to resell.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
While many young people in Africa dream of getting well-paying jobs, Godfrey, 22, from the Litein area of Kenya, never got one. He decided that he will be independent and contribute to his community by practicing mixed farming. 

Godfrey and his wife have been blessed with one angel who is their heartbeat, and they have named him Ian. 

His primary sources of income are milk selling, vegetables, poultry farming and some personal business that he does to supplement his meager income. 

Deciding to practice poultry farming for Godfrey was not difficult. “I was brought up with chickens raised by my grandfather and grandmother,” Godfrey said. “It is in my blood.” 

For the past three years, Godfrey has been earning a decent income from poultry farming. The income sources of Godfrey are very perishable and they require timely delivery to the market, but one problem that he faces is delivering to the market on time. The Kitale area has a poor road network and poor feeder roads that really hamper timely delivery of products to the market; that is why Godfrey is kindly seeking a loan to buy a motorbike. Through the motorbike he will deliver products to the market on time and reap more profits because the products will still be fresh. 

Godfrey is very determined to succeed, and because he is much disciplined with finances, he plans that through accumulated profits he will be able to provide a secure future for himself and also for his parents. 

Geoffrey’s dream is to go back to school and he hopes that through your loan, you will help him realize his dream.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to deliver his fresh poultry products to the market

loans.name: Lia

texts.en:
Lia is a 50-year-old woman from Ambrolauri district. She is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, she has a cow and produces dairy products to sell. Besides this, she has a plot of agricultural land, where walnut trees are grown. She sells the harvested products at a good price. 

Lia decided to start her own business and has requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables her to get a loan of 2,000 Gel. With the received credit she will purchase clothes to sell and increase her income. Lia awaits your support.

loans.use: to begin a clothes trading business.

loans.name: Saydati Group

texts.en:
This group is called Saydati. It consists of four women from Sana'a city, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 160,000 YER (Yemen rials) from AMB.

Altaf is the leader of the group. She is a 27-year-old married woman and a mother of two children. Her oldest child is 12 years old, and the youngest one is 5 years old. She is living with them in a humble house. The income of her husband is not enough to cover the necessary needs of the family. 

From her side, Altaf decided to help him in improving the household living standards. For this reason, she decided to purchase an amount of materials to make local incense and perfumes of different kinds and types to sell to the people in local markets. 

She is a very active and dynamic woman and works hard to enlarge her business more, but she doesn't have enough money to do so; therefore, she applied for a loan of 30,000 YER to purchase incense and perfume materials to make different types of those goods (local incense and perfumes) to sell to the people in the local markets.

Altaf hopes to expand her business through export of her products outside of the country. She is a very ambitious woman.

loans.use: to purchase incense and perfume materials to make different types of local incense and perfumes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay her university installments for this semester.

loans.name: Esther Rosmery

texts.es:
Esther es una joven mujer de 19 años de edad, soltera sin hijos y se dedica al estudio del idioma inglés y lingüística.
Ella es inteligente, responsable, comprometida, constante, dulce, cariñosa, sensible y sincera. Sus estudios lo realiza en un instituto comercial en la zona de Pampahasi, lugar caracterizado por sus orígenes; campesino aymaras que pelearon por la liberación del yugo español y se asentaron en ese lugar como trinchera.
Esther es de tez morena, cabello negro largo peinado a la moda, su lengua materna es el aymara el cual ya no utiliza porque estudia y vive en la ciudad. Su vida la realiza junto a sus padres que trabajan como transportista y su madre tiene una tienda de barrio, todos viven en una casa propia que cuenta con los servicios de luz y agua. Esta es la primera secuencia de préstamos con la institución. Ella cursa la carrera de idiomas y se encuentra en segundo año de cinco años que dura la carrera; disfruta traduciendo un texto, se entusiasma aprendiendo la fonética de las diferentes lenguas y le gustaría hablar todos los idiomas del mundo. Su sueño es ser profesional y conseguir un buen empleo. Ella desea realizar la compra de libros y una computadora portátil para facilitar su forma de estudio.
Es por esos motivos que Esther solicita un préstamo para la compra de una computadora portátil para terminar su carrera profesional.
texts.en:
Esther is a 19-year-old young woman. She's single, has no children, and is dedicated to studying English and linguistics. She is intelligent, responsible, committed, constant, sweet, caring, sensible and sincere.

She studies in a commercial institute in the Pampahasi zone, an area known for its original people: Aymara peasants who fought for liberation from Spanish rule and settled in this area as a trench.

Esther has dark skin and black hair styled fashionably. Her native language is Aymara, which she doesn't use because she studies and lives in the city. She lives her life together with her parents, who work in transportation, and her mother has a neighborhood store. They all live in their own house which has light and water. 

This is the first series of loans with the institution. She is studying for a degree in languages and is currently in her second of five years for the degree. She enjoys translating texts and is enthusiastic about learning the phonetics of different languages. She would like to speak every language in the world. 

Her dream is to be a professional and find a good job. She wants to buy books and a laptop computer to facilitate her form of studying. Because of these goals, Esther seeks a loan to buy a laptop computer to finish her professional degree.

loans.use: to buy a laptop computer to finish her professional degree.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 35 years old, married, and together with his spouse, has been blessed with three children. He has a computer services business and has been running it for seven years. He also has a poultry business, and it has been profitable.

He will be using this loan to buy more stock of feeds for his poultry, as well as medicine to treat them. He will use the anticipated profits to start a poultry hatchery project and become a successful poultry farmer. 

This is his second loan term with VisionFund Kenya, and he paid his previous loans successfully. His future hopes are to expand his business, make more income and be able to improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: To buy more stock of poultry feeds for his poultry, as well as medicine to treat them

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena works hard to support her family. Elena is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

She requested a 9,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase a new bundle of fishing net.

Elena has been in this business for 15 years now.

In the future, Elena would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase a new bundle of fishing net

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is married, and she works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming sugarcane. Susan is borrowing 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell for her general store business.

Susan has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is 45 years old and married with four children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. She is a businesswoman who deals in cocoa buying and selling and cassava flour. This business is her source of income, but she also has cocoa gardens. She has been in this business for 15 years and hopes to use some of the proceeds from this business to buy her own land.

Violet will use the loan to pay school fees for her children and buy cocoa for selling.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children and buy cocoa for selling.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a thirty-year-old married woman with five children living in Bundibugyo-Uganda. She works hard to keep her business running to maximize her  profit. She faces challenges of seasonality and price fluctuations.

She serves both men and women and hopes to expand her business in future. She wants a loan to buy food stuffs to sell.

loans.use: to buy food stuffs to sell.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine works hard to support her family. Geraldine is married and has a bakery business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 7000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients like milk, sugar, flour, etc.

Geraldine has been in this business for 1 year now.

She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients like milk, sugar, flour, etc.

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en:
Faridah is a hardworking woman living in Masindi-Uganda. She sells used clothes along side her farming work. She started the business to earn a living  and educate her children. She has a great hope of expanding her business to new markets but inadequate capital hinders her business.

Faridah wants a loan to buy second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Genelyn

texts.en:
Genelyn is 50 years old and married with one child.

She works hard to provide for her family and has run a general store for 5 years.  She requests 7,000 PHP through NWTF to buy canned goods, egg, noodles, and chips.

Genelyn has successfully borrowed and repaid 1 loan from NWTF. She earn an income raising pigs.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, egg, noodles, and chips.

loans.name: Kathia  Massiel

texts.es:
Kathia es una joven de 21 años que sueña con convertirse en una arquitecta en Diseño Gráfico, meta que no falta mucho para concretar. Desde pequeña, ella ha tenido pocos recursos económicos que en momentos pensó que no podría terminar sus estudios. Sin embargo, ahora se encuentra en el cuarto año y a punto de graduarse como licenciada en Arquitectura en Diseño Gráfico. Actualmente trabaja como recepcionista para pagar sus estudios y gastos personales.
Kathia es conocida por sus amistades como una joven optimista, estudiosa, emprendedora y muy creativa, razón por la cual todos comentan que no se ha equivocado de carrera. Ella está solicitando un crédito para pagar su graduación y su título universitario, encendiendo las velas del pastel de su gran día como licenciada. Entre sus planes está culminar sus estudios, estudiar otra carrera y poder desempeñarse profesionalmente en el campo que ella estudió.
texts.en:
Kathia is a young 21 year old who dreams with becoming a graphic design architect, a goal which she is close to achieving. Since she was very young, she has enjoyed few economic resources which at time led her to believe she would not be able to finish her studies. However, she is currently in the fourth year and about to graduate as a licensed Graphic Design Architect. 
She currently works as a receptionist to pay for her studies and personal expenses. Kathia is known by her friends as an optimistic young lady, studious, ambitious and very creative. This is why they all agree that she was not mistaken in her career choice. 
She is requesting a loan to pay for her graduation and her university degree, lighting the candles on the cake during her big day as a licensed professional. Among her plans is to complete her studies, study another career and be able to perform well professionally in the field she studied.

loans.use: pay for graduation and her university degree.

loans.name: Tsitsino

texts.en:
Tsitsino is 64 years old widowed woman from the village of Boriti. She has a son and daughter-in-law who are temporarily unemployed. To take care of her family’s everyday needs, Tsitsino is engaged in cattle and sheep breeding and in the cultivation of family-owned agricultural land. She sells the agricultural products in the local market, which is the main source of her family’s income. However, the income is insufficient for covering even their basic needs and so they live in poverty. 

Now, Tsitsino needs financial support to purchase a mini bus and start trading fruits and vegetables in nearby villages. This will allow her to continue running her business but in a more profitable way. Tsitsino has been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. She will sell various kinds of harvested fruits and vegetables and will get her own customers from selling the fresh products door-to-door with the help of her son. The loan will greatly assist Tsitsino and she will be able to improve her economic situation and give her family a better lifestyle.

loans.use: to purchase a mini bus and start trading with fruits and vegetables in nearby villages

loans.name: Daod

texts.en:
Daod is a 29-year-old single man, living with his family in a miserable condition in Sana'a city, Yemen. 

He is an educated man with a maintenance diploma, and an employee in an electricity station. His salary from this job is very small and not enough to cover the necessary needs of his family.  The house where Daod and his family live lacks a lot of furniture. 

All people these days suffer from the cold because of the winter season. Doad's family do not have enough blankets inside the house to face the winter and they do not have enough money. 

For this reason, Daod applied for a Youth loan of 130,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase blankets for his house. Daod hopes to cover his house with all needed furniture. He looks forward to starting his own business by opening a commercial store.

loans.use: to purchase blankets for his house.

loans.name: Mimo Group

texts.en:
Houeida is the featured borrower of Mimo group. She got together with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua, because they have always been neighbors, relatives and friends, and they all seek the best for their families.

Houeida is a 38-year-old married mother of three children. She has been working for five years from her house, selling beauty cosmetics and home products, to support her husband in covering their beloved family's needs and requests.

Houeida is working hard to develop her business as much as she can through increasing her business capital to cover almost all of her customers requests. Unfortunately, she can't save some of her acquired income, in addition to her husband's, because they have limited monthly income to cover their living needs.

She is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to increase her business merchandise with newly released items with special offers, especially for the coming autumn and winter seasons.

She is very anxious about this loan and working hard to make sure she will invest it in a profitable way.

Houeida is the lady standing at the center of the picture. As for the other group members, Denise is a 30-year-old married lady, standing at the far right side of the picture, who works as a hairdresser. She is investing her loan portion for her expected baby's needs and delivery expenses.

Mirvat, Houeida's sister, standing at the far left side of the picture, is a 30-year-old single lady who will invest her loan portion in covering some of her wedding expenses.

loans.use: to increase her business merchandise with newly released items for the coming autumn and winter seasons.

loans.name: Rhea Mae

texts.en:
Rhea Mae is 30 years old and has three children. Rhea Mae is married, and two children are currently in school.

Rhea Mae is in the agricultural business, farming vegetables in the Philippines. Rhea Mae requested a 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Rhea Mae has been farming vegetables for six years now, and has borrowed five times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Rhea Mae would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Nena works hard to support her family.

She has a dried fish making business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 5,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to purchase additional fish to make dried fish for her dried fish making business.

Nena has been sustaining her business activities through her past one loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to make dried fish

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, a 32-year-old farmer from Rongena, a remote village in the Litein area of Kenya, is elegant and admirable in spirit and effort. He is a role model, a mentor and an inspiration to many young farmers in his village because of his resilience despite personal challenges and his passion to support his four children as a primary caregiver. 

For the past 5 years he has been involved in mixed farming, and his primary source of income has been growing maize, cabbage, tomatoes and also keeping dairy cows. John has been able to provide nutritious food for his family. After his wife lost her formal job, the role of primary caregiver of the family fell to John. It has been overwhelming because he now has to shoulder the responsibility of feeding the whole family. This challenge has not made him give up. “I have to do something for my family," he said. 

John is requesting a loan to buy an additional quality dairy cow. The dairy cow that he plans to buy is not just an ordinary cow, but it’s a quality breed of dairy cow that will be producing between 10 and 20 liters of milk a day. This will immediately translate to more profits and increased income levels. Profits from selling milk will be used in repaying the loan in full, and the extra income will be used to increase his business enterprise. 

John is very visionary, and he intends that in the near future, he will start adding value to his milk business through packaging the milk before selling it. He will also start selling dairy products such as yoghurt. An improved income level will assure his family of a secure future. By joining Juhudi Kilimo, which assists smallholder farmers, he will also benefit from free extension services and links to markets. John believes that if male farmers had access to resources the number of the world's hungry could be reduced by half.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Rovin

texts.en:
Listening to Rovin refer to the different breeds of dairy cows on his compound, one would mistake him for an Agricultural Extension Officer. 

Rovin, from Kitale, a remote town in Kenya, is an active and progressive farmer in his locality. He has a wife and child and  lives on a small piece of land. His primary source of income has been eggs, crops, and personal business. He has farmed for 5 years and has gained so much experience that he is always ranked the best farmer in his village. 

Kenyans drink a lot of milk. This tradition is probably derived from tribal culture, particularly the Maasai tribe where cows represent wealth. Demand for dairy milk has been high and Rovin wants to take advantage of the market. His products are perishable and require timely delivery to the market. Making delivers to the market on time is difficult. The Kitale area has a poor road network and feeder roads. This hamper timely delivery of products to the market; that is why Rovin seeks a loan to buy a motorbike.   The motorbike will help him to deliver products to the market on time and reap more profits because the products will still be fresh. 

Rovin has faced financial challenges  but feels relieved knowing that institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva are there to make his dream come true. Rovin chose Juhudi Kilimo because the interest rate on their loan is low. Rovin received training through Juhudi Kilimo and during the training season, he learned that saving is a continuous process in many micro finance institutions. Through accumulated profits, Rovin plans to permanently improve his living conditions and secure the future of his school-aged children by paying tuition fees.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Al- Arij Al- Sonina Group

texts.en:
Al-Arij Al-Sonina is a group which is comprised of three women from Sana'a, Yemen. They are requesting a loan of 270,000 Yemeni rials (YER) from AMB.

Takia is the leader of the group. She is a 44-year-old married woman with five children. Takia keeps many kinds of drinks, sweets, and water in her kitchen, but she does not have a refrigerator to keep them cold. As a result, most of their food and drinks expire quickly and develop a bad taste. Takia wants to purchase a refrigerator for the house to keep their food and drinks cold, but she doesn't have enough money. Thus, she is requesting a loan of 90,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase a refrigerator for the house.

Takia looks forward to improving her family's living conditions through purchasing appliances for her house.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator for the house.

loans.name: Ambrose

texts.en: Ambrose is a 32-year-old married man with three (3) children who attend school. He is in the coffee trade at Nyabiteete, Bugangari Sub County, and this is his major source of income. He has been engaged in his business for a period of five (5) years; however, he is affected by limited capital, which hinders him from expanding the business. Ambrose applied for a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) to boost his business, earn more income, meet all his family's financial needs, and construct his own house. Ambrose and his family thank Ugafode for this financial assistance, which they hope will improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy coffee for trade

loans.name: Nahayat

texts.en:
Nahayat is a 40-year-old woman, residing in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. She is a mother of four children. Nahayat has been running her own beauty salon for many years and also contributes her income, with her husbands, to manage the household. 

Nahayat needs to buy different types of cosmetics (i.e creams, hair brush, and other accessories) for her beauty salon. Due to financial constraints, she is not capable to buy these items for business purposes, so Nahayat has applied for Kiva loan. This loan will help her to buy the relevant items for her business purposes so that she can provide better services to her customers. It will also help her to earn the maximum profitable income to fulfill the needs of her business and family.

For this financial assistance Nahayat is very grateful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of cosmetics and accessories for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman with three children. She owns a house that has electricity but not running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Eunice operates a food making business to make beans, chapati (flat bread) and sell them to passersby and neighbors. She will use 15,000 KES to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking fat oil, sugar, and beans. 

She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking fat oil, sugar, and beans.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a 19-year-old single man from Jabalia. He lives with his parents in a small humble house. His father has a grocery store in the city where he gets a fair income. This is the only source of income for the family. 

Mohammad is a student in a local university where he studies elementary education. He would like to take a BA degree and find a job as a teacher to support his family. 

Mohammad took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new laptop for his study. By taking this loan, Mohammad will be able to do his homework and write reports easily.

Mohammad appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for his study.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cheese in bulk.

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en:
Batjargal, 50 years old, lives with his wife, daughter and son in Kherlen, the easternmost town of Mongolia. He has been working as a guard at a high school since 2003. His wife has retired from work and stays home, taking care of the domestic work. Their daughter works at a supermarket while their son studies at university. 

The house they live in has deteriorated over the years so he is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 MNT to buy building materials such as bricks, cement, fiberglass and foam for house renovation. After renovation, his family will live in a comfortable and warm place where less coal is burned and less pollutants are released into the air.

loans.use: to renovate his house in order to burn less coal for heating.

loans.name: Amigas Inseparables Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “AMIGAS INSEPARABLES” iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Villa Exaltación, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Mónica es la Tesorera. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de refrescos, venta de  dulces y pasankallas, venta de pollos, repostería, venta de ropa, venta de tenis, venta de libros.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Mónica es integrante, ella indica que hace dos años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de un promotor de la institución que fue a visitarle a su domicilio. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de refresco y pan; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió de  su familia, ya que tienen el mismo negocio, es por ello que con un pequeño capital decide independizarse.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de su mercadería (compra de pan por mayor) que lo adquirirá de las vendedoras de la ciudad de La Paz, posteriormente lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella vive en unión libre y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.

En la imagen esta ausente una cliente, la misma se encuentra en en el consultorio médico.
texts.en:
The A.C. “AMIGAS INSEPARABLES” (Inseparable Friends) will start the first cycle in Pro Mujer as part of the Focal Center of Villa Exaltation.  The group is made up of eight members and is directed by a board where Mrs. Mónica is the treasurer. The businesses that the members of the community association are carrying forward are various: sale of soft drinks, sale of candy and corn treats, sale of chicken, pastry production, sale of clothes, sale of shoes and sale of books. 

The loan that they are requesting will benefit a group of small microentrepreneurs of which Mrs. Mónica is a member.  She mentions that two years ago she became a member of Pro Mujer, joining after a staff member from the institution invited her to join during a home visit.   She currently has a business selling soft drinks and bread, which she mentions that she learnt from her family. They already have the same type of business, which is why with a bit of capital she decided to become independent.  

The loan which she is currently requesting is to increase her merchandise (to buy bread in bulk) which she will obtain from saleswomen in the city of La Paz, to then sell later in her retail space. This way of working allows her to generate resources to help her family financially as she lives with a common law partner and has 3 children.     

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer she says she enjoys the trainings which the institution offers.  

In the image one of the clients is absent as she is at the doctor’s office.

loans.use: to buy bread in bulk

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad, who appears in the photo above, is a 22-year-old married man from Rafah. He lives with his wife, one small son, and his parents in a small, humble house. His father works as an employee in the public sector, where he earns a low income. This is the only source of income for the family. Mohammad is a student at a local university, where he studies elementary education. He would like to earn a B.A. degree and find a job as a teacher to support his family.

Mohammad took out a loan in U.S. dollars from FATEN. This loan will help him buy a new laptop for his studies. By taking out this loan, Mohammad will be able to do his homework and write reports easily.

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for his studies

loans.name: Banana Group

texts.en:
Christina is in her mid 30s, married, and has three children, two of whom attend school. She has been running a poultry business for two years.  She works from 5 AM to 7PM daily and is able to earn a good monthly profit.

Christina requested her first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she will use to buy chicks and chicken feeds.  She dreams of expanding her poultry business. Christina  will share this loan with the Banana Group, which consists of two members who will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

loans.use: to buy chicks and  chicken feeds.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
As a married mother of five children, Josefina works hard to support her family.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store, pig fattening and food vending businesses. Josefina is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF in order to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farm.

Josefina has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farm.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Analyn works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying & selling rice. Analyn is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell like canned goods, eggs, soft drinks, etc for her general store business.

Analyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 2 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell like canned goods, eggs, soft drinks, etc

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is a hardworking man living in Masindi, Uganda. He operates a transport business for hire. He wishes to educate his children up to University level. The poor roads that lead to constant mechanical break downs affecting his business. Samuel wants a loan to repair his car.

loans.use: to repair his car.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is married and works hard to support her family. She operates a fish vending business in the Philippines, which she has been doing for 20 years.

Rosalie requested a loan from NWTF for 5,000 PHP, which she will use to buy additional fishing net. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishing net

loans.name: Ntuntu Mother's Group B

texts.en:
Harriet is a 46-year-old single woman with three children living in Kamwenge, Uganda. She owns a grocery as her main source of income, although she involves herself in village health team work as her side income. It is from these businesses that she has been able to sustain herself and educate her children. Low income and competition are a problem, but she has hopes of educating her children to higher levels.

Harriet is requesting a loan to buy tomatoes, groundnuts and millet to sell.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, groundnuts and millet to sell.

loans.name: Marmolie

texts.en:
Marmolie is a married woman with two children.  She works hard to support her family.

She has a general store and  earns additional income from a restaurant. Marmolie requests 7,000 PHP through NWTF to buy soap, sugar, egg, and noodles for her general store.

Marmolie has sustained her business through a previous loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream which is to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy  soap, sugar, egg, and noodles.

loans.name: Rosemyr

texts.en:
Rosemyr works hard to support her family. She is married and has a dried fish making business in the Philippines. Rosemyr has been in this business for 10 years now.

She requested a 5,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional fish to make dried fish.

In the future, Rosemyr would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional fish to make dried fish.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema a 29-year-old married woman with four children living in Bundibugyo-Uganda. 

She started a food stall business four years ago and has a cocoa garden  to supplement her income.  She hopes to expand her business,  even though the changing seasons present a major challenge.

She wants a loan to buy food items to sell.

loans.use: to buy food items.

loans.name: Al- Ahlia Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al- Ahlia. It consists of four women from Sana'a city, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 200,000 YER (Yemen rials) from AMB.

Jamila is the leader of the group. She is a 40-year-old married woman and a mother of two children. The house where she lives with her family is not renovated from the inside and it is very old, as well.

Jamila works as a teacher in a private school with a petty salary which is not enough to cover the necessary needs of the family, and her house needs to be renovated, but Jamila doesn't have enough money to do so; therefore, she applied for a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase construction materials to renovate the house from the inside.

Jamila hopes to complete all the renovation of the house to make it more safe for living in.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials to renovate the house from the inside.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married, and has one child. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for the family.

For the past seven years, she has operated a fruit juice selling business. She sells to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenges are high cost of transportation to her place of operation.

With the loan of 20,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of fruit and sugar for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruit and sugar for her business

loans.name: Benon

texts.en:
Benon is a hardworking man living in Kamwenge, Uganda. He owns a retail shop which he started to meet his needs and realize development. He earns additional income from farming. 

Benon is requesting a loan, which he will use to buy materials to complete his house. He hopes to be a prominent businessman.

loans.use: to purchase materials to complete his house.

loans.name: Mbeyu

texts.en:
Mbeyu is a married woman with three kids, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Mbeyu operates a grocery and vegetable selling stall. She sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces the challenge of a high cost of transportation to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a motorcycle transport business in the future. 

With the loan of Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase green vegetables, two crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, two crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale.

loans.name: Gulshan

texts.en:
Gulshan is a 42-year-old active borrower of BRAC Pakistan. She is a mother of four children. Gulshan has been doing her business of selling clothes for many years and contributes her income with her husband's to manage the household.

Gulshan needs to buy different varieties of clothes for reselling purposes, but due to insufficient financial means, she is not in the position to buy these clothes for her business. Therefore, she has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. With the help of this loan she can purchase the clothes easily to fulfill her business needs so that she can earn more profitable income to support her family and business.

For this financial assistance, Gulshan is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy a variety of clothes for her clothing business.

loans.name: Tamer

texts.en:
Tamer is a 27-year-old single young man from Jabalia. He lives with his family in a small humble house. His brother is a construction worker and earns a low, unstable income. This is the only source of income to the family. 

Tamer is a student in a local university and studies elementary education. He would like to earn a BA degree and find a job as a teacher to support his family. He bought a laptop last year but it has been destroyed due to the violence in Gaza.

Tamer took a USD loan from FATEN to buy a new laptop for his studies. Tamer will be able to do his home work and easily write the reports.

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for his studies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 48 years old and is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Teresita has a food vending business in the Philippines. Teresita requested a PHP 5000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food business.

Teresita has been in this business for two years. In the future, Teresita would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business.

loans.name: Nora Leonor

texts.en:
Nora Leonor is 40 years old and married with one child in school.

Nora Leonor works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Nora Leonor has been in this business for eleven years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Nora Leonor aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell so she can expand her little store.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios works hard to support her family and has had a fish vending business for 11 years.

She requests 12,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional fish to sell.

She would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy  fish to sell.

loans.name: Maria Francisca

texts.es:
María de 49 años de edad, está acompañada, cuando era joven en la comunidad donde vivía no había escuela cerca y no contaban con los recursos económicos para mandarla a estudiar, por lo que no tuvo accesos a la educación. Su esposo es agricultor y con él han procreado 3 hijos que están estudiando. Con ella viven su esposo y sus tres hijos y solo sus hijos dependen de ella.

María tiene 15 años de dedicarse al oficio de elaboración de hamacas, aprendió en su comunidad asistiendo a un taller que se impartió hace 15 años. Decidió dedicarse a esto porque lo disfruta, además no requiere de esfuerzo físico y lo puede hacer en su casa.. María también es cocinera, trabaja en la escuela de su comunidad, es la encargada de la preparación de los alimentos que les dan a los alumnos en la escuela, la escuela está a unos 2 minutas caminando desde su casa.

El préstamo será utilizado para comprar material para la elaboración de hamacas, hilo nylon, de seda y corriente,  además para comprar fertilizantes, pesticidas para aplicar a la parcela de maíz que tiene sembrada su esposo. María espera alcanzar una buena producción de maíz, para guardar para su familia y vender los excedentes, también piensa fabricar otra clase de artesanías para tener más que ofrecer a los clientes.
texts.en:
María is 49 years old and has a life partner.  When she was young there was no school near the community where she lived and her family didn't have the money to send her away to study, so she had no access to education. Her husband is a farmer and together they have three children who are all in school. They all live together and only her children are dependent upon her.

Maria has been making hammocks for 15  years. She learned how to do this by going to a workshop that was held in her community 15  years ago. She decided to do this work because she enjoys it and it also doesn't require much physical effort, and she can do it in her home. 

Maria is also a cook. She works at the local school where she is in charge of preparing meals for the school children. The school is only a two minute walk from her house.

The loan will be used to buy materials for making hammocks, including nylon, silk and ordinary yarns and also to buy fertilizer and pesticides to apply to her husband's corn field. She hopes they get a good crop of corn which the family will use for their own consumption, and then sell whatever is left over. Maria is also thinking of making other types of handicrafts so she can have more to offer her customers.

loans.use: to buy nylon, silk and ordinary yarns as well as fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita, 49, is a married woman with four children. All four of her children are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur, who has a fishing business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for six years.

Anecita requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF. She will use it to buy additional materials to use in her business, like fishing net, gasoline, etc.

In the future, Anecita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional materials to use in her business, like fishing net and gasoline

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy an assortment of grains, groceries, and drinks.

loans.name: Festo

texts.en:
Festo, a new client to the institution, is married with three children who attend school. He drives a taxi as his major source of income; this is a business he has done for over five years. 

Festo applied for a loan of UGX 3,000,000 to complete payment of his car, which he uses for special hire. 

Festo thanks UGAFODE for the financial assistance, which enabled him to own a car. He encourages UGAFODE and the Kiva lenders to continue supporting low-income earners.

loans.use: to complete payment on a car for his taxi business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase construction materials to renovate her house from the inside to make it safe to live in.

loans.name: Naheed

texts.en:
Naheed, 48, lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. With her five children. Naheed provides sewing services and earns income to contribute with her husband to manage the household. 

She needs a different new sewing machine for her business, but due to insufficient financial means, she is unable to purchase one. Therefore she has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. This loan will enable her to purchase a sewing machine, which will help her to increase her monthly sales and profit by providing better sewing services.

Naheed is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine for her sewing business.

loans.name: Juralyn

texts.en:
Juralyn is 36 years old and lives in Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is widowed with one child now school-aged.
